trans-unit.source: Introduction
trans-unit.target: はじめに

trans-unit.source: Any collector of coins, fossils, or baseball cards knows that at some point you need to have a way to organize everything so you can find things.
trans-unit.target: コイン、化石、野球カードなどの収集家はある時点で、自分のコレクションからアイテムを探しやすくするために、コレクションの内容全てうまく整理する必要があることに気づきます。

trans-unit.source: For example, a rock collector might have a tray of specimens numbered like this:
trans-unit.target: たとえば岩石の収集家は以下のようなやり方で、トレーの上の標本それぞれに番号を割り当てるでしょう：

trans-unit.source: /static/courses/csintro/arrays/rock-collection.png
trans-unit.target: /static/courses/csintro/arrays/rock-collection.png

trans-unit.source: Rock collection is an array
trans-unit.target: Rock collection is 配列

trans-unit.source: Every rock in the collection needs its own storage space, and a unique address so you can find it later.
trans-unit.target: コレクションのひとつひとつの岩石には、独自の保存スペースと、後でそれを見つけるための一意のアドレスが必要です。

trans-unit.source: As your MakeCode programs get more and more complicated, and require more variables to keep track of things, you will want to find a way to store and organize all of your data.
trans-unit.target: As your MakeCode programs get more and more complicated, and require more variables to keep track of things, you will want to find a way to store and organize all of your data.

trans-unit.source: MakeCode provides a special category for just this purpose, called an Array.
trans-unit.target: MakeCode provides a special category for just this purpose, called 配列.

trans-unit.source: Arrays can store numbers, strings (words), or sprites. They can also store musical notes.
trans-unit.target: Arrays can store numbers, strings (words), or sprites. They can also store musical notes.

trans-unit.source: Every spot in an array can be identified by its index, which is a number that corresponds to its location in the array. The first slot in an array is index 0, just like our rock collection above.
trans-unit.target: Every spot in 配列 can be identified by its index, which is a number that corresponds to its location in 配列. The first slot in 配列 is index 0, just like our rock collection above.

trans-unit.source:
The length of an array refers to the total number of items in the array, and the index of the last element in an array is always one less than its length (because the array numbering starts at zero.)
In MakeCode, you can create an array by assigning it to a variable.
trans-unit.target:
The length of 配列 refers to the total number of items in 配列, and the index of the last element in 配列 is always one less than its length (because 配列 numbering starts at zero.)
In MakeCode, you can create 配列 by assigning it to 変数.

trans-unit.source: The Array blocks can be found under the Advanced Toolbox menu.
trans-unit.target: The 配列ブロック can be found under the 高度なブロック(Advanced)メニュー.

trans-unit.source: /static/courses/csintro/arrays/arrays-menu.png
trans-unit.target: /static/courses/csintro/arrays/arrays-menu.png

trans-unit.source: Arrays block menu
trans-unit.target: 配列(Arrays)メニュー

trans-unit.source: The code above creates an empty array called list, then fills it with five numbers, indexed from 0 to 4.
trans-unit.target: The code above creates an empty array called list, then fills it with five numbers, indexed from 0 to 4.

trans-unit.source: The index of the first value (4) is 0.
trans-unit.target: The index of the first value (4) is 0.

trans-unit.source: The index of the second value (2) is 1.
trans-unit.target: The index of the second value (2) is 1.

trans-unit.source: The index of the last value (3) is 4.
trans-unit.target: The index of the last value (3) is 4.

trans-unit.source: You can get items out of the array by specifying its index like this:
trans-unit.target: You can get items out of 配列 by specifying its index like this:

trans-unit.source: ```blocks let list = [4, 2, 5, 1, 3]
trans-unit.target: ```blocks let list = [4, 2, 5, 1, 3]

trans-unit.source: There are lots of other blocks in the Arrays Toolbox drawer.
trans-unit.target: There are lots of other blocks in the 配列(Arrays)メニュー.

trans-unit.source: The next few Activities will introduce you to them.
trans-unit.target: The next few Activities will introduce you to them.

trans-unit.source: Discussion
trans-unit.target: Discussion

trans-unit.source: Ask your students if any of them collects anything. What is it? Comic books, cards, coins, stamps, books, etc.
trans-unit.target: Ask your students if any of them collects anything. What is it? Comic books, cards, coins, stamps, books, etc.

trans-unit.source: How big is the collection?
trans-unit.target: How big is the collection?

trans-unit.source: How is it organized?
trans-unit.target: How is it organized?

trans-unit.source: Are the items sorted in any way?
trans-unit.target: Are the items sorted in any way?

trans-unit.source:
How would you go about finding a particular item in the collection?
In the discussion, see if you can explore the following array vocabulary words in the context of kids’ personal collections.
trans-unit.target:
How would you go about finding a particular item in the collection?
In the discussion, see if you can explore the following array vocabulary words in the context of kids’ personal collections.

trans-unit.source: Length: the total number of items in the collection
trans-unit.target: Length: the total number of items in the collection

trans-unit.source: Sort: Items in the collection are ordered by a particular attribute (e.g., date, price, name)
trans-unit.target: Sort: Items in the collection are ordered by a particular attribute (e.g., date, price, name)

trans-unit.source: Index: A unique address or location in the collection
trans-unit.target: Index: A unique address or location in the collection

trans-unit.source: Type: The type of item being stored in the collection
trans-unit.target: Type: The type of item being stored in the collection

trans-unit.source: References
trans-unit.target: References

trans-unit.source: Once you start saving lots of different values in an array, you will probably want to have some way to sort those values.
trans-unit.target: Once you start saving lots of different values in 配列, you will probably want to have some way to sort those values.

trans-unit.source: Many languages already implement a sorting algorithm that students can call upon as needed.
trans-unit.target: Many languages already implement a ソートアルゴリズム that students can call upon as needed.

trans-unit.source: However, understanding how those different sorting algorithms work is an important part of computer science, and as students go on to further study they will learn other algorithms, as well as their relative efficiency.
trans-unit.target: However, understanding how those different sorting algorithms work is an important part of computer science, and as students go on to further study they will learn other algorithms, as well as their relative efficiency.

trans-unit.source: There are some good array sorting videos:
trans-unit.target: There are some good array sorting videos:

trans-unit.source: Visually displays a number of different types of sorts: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kPRA0W1kECg
trans-unit.target: Visually displays a number of different types of sorts: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kPRA0W1kECg

trans-unit.target: Select-sort with Gypsy folk dance: https://youtu.be/Ns4TPTC8whw
